rows.question: So you’re just like any other media company?
rows.answer: Actually, most of us came from traditional media companies that raced toward the same goal: Get bigger. The problem with that approach is that it minimizes the most important piece of making culture: Creators. We’ve built a company around creators.

rows.question: How do I know what kind of story you’re looking for?
rows.answer: You know that idea twitching in your mind? The one you know the culture needs? That story you can’t help but obsess over to the detriment of your irl functioning? We’re all ears.

rows.title: Can you walk me through the submissions process step by step?
rows.question: Can you walk me through the submissions process step by step?
rows.answer:
1. You pitch us through the submissions portal
2. We read every pitch, and respond promptly.
3. If we do not like your pitch, we let you know.
4. If we like your pitch, we let you know. We talk again. Probably in person if we can, and over some sort of beverage, depending on your beverage preference.
5. If that works out, we talk a lot more. Definitely in person, and probably over food, also depending on your food preference. Throughout all these conversations, together we’ll figure out what this project really is, what we want to do, what you need to pull it off, what we feel like we can contribute, what the budget is, the timeline, the greatest potential for it, etc. We’ll also find time to talk about art and storytelling and ideas that move us, because this is what we talk about with people we are getting to know.

And we actually think like creators.</gsx:answer></entry>
rows.title: This still feels like more of the same. What’s different about Matter?
rows.question: This still feels like more of the same. What’s different about Matter?
rows.answer: We’re not interested in injecting content into the world to get the clicks to get the cash. In fact, stepping outside of the daily churn allows us to make real cultural impact in a way that is ultimately more profitable and better for creators. And we actually think like creators.

rows.question: How so?
rows.answer: Our projects live across platforms, which is how creators actually make stuff nowadays. Media companies aren’t necessarily set up to work that way.

rows.title: Why should I trust you?
rows.question: Why should I trust you?
rows.answer: Studies have shown that our brain takes three hundredths of a second to decide to trust someone. Which is to say we’re dumb animals and live our modern lives in constant negotiation with millennia of evolution. Some people default to trust until a person gives you a reason not to, other people are more in the guilty-until-proven-trustworthy camp. No matter where you with Matter w/r/t the trust question, know that we’re a transparent company (but actually), we want to help incredible storytellers thrive, and we care deeply about our work.

rows.title: Isn’t Matter a magazine?
rows.question: Isn’t Matter a magazine?
rows.answer: Yes. Matter was Medium’s flagship magazine, which published acclaimed narrative non fiction on non-offending pedophiles, the Syrian civil war, sex work, and the sham of Mars One. We created extremely NSFW illustrated essays on sexting; devoted an entire month to a conversation about trans issues by trans voices; and crowd-sourced a sprawling investigation into the refugee crisis. We made lots and lots of beautiful things and won prestigious awards for them.

rows.title: Does Matter the magazine still exist?
rows.question: Does Matter the magazine still exist?
rows.answer: Absolutely. We’re just expanding Matter into books, documentaries, video series, audio series, twitter bots, tarot cards, and any other platform(s) your idea demands.

rows.title: Will the magazine still publish on Medium?
rows.question: Will the magazine still publish on Medium?
rows.answer: Yes, the magazine will still publish amazing, boundary-pushing stories, series, and special issues, and we’ll be building plenty of new publications and pop-ups online and in print (print!) as we go. Because, think about it. Stories with raw, provocative feeling; from individual, electric voices; filled with fearless thinking and deep reporting; explored inside experimental, participatory formats; covering topics of profound social value—this will always be Matter’s DNA.

rows.title: What’s the exact deal with Medium and Matter?
rows.question: What’s the exact deal with Medium and Matter?
rows.answer: Ev Williams, the CEO of Medium, is the chairman of and sole investor in Matter Studios. But we are a fully separate company from the growing publishing platform: separate operating budget, separate office, separate Slack, separate goals, separate ambitions, separate staff.

rows._xml: <entry><id>https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/1rzbzTQuAzRhv_QpU7fkQ1IeMj35Z1AVdKTkGxq4aOmw/od6/public/values/dnp34</id><updated>2016-10-26T01:21:50.928Z</updated><category scheme='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006' term='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006#list'/><title type='text'>Who’s on your staff?</title><content type='text'>answer: <img class="image image--team" src="./assets/img/team.jpg"><br>We’ve hand-picked a team of empaths who love making things and each other and making things with each other. We practice extreme transparency, collaborate on all decisions, and, to be honest, are simply v into each other. <a class="link" href="https://www.google.com/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&rlz=1C5CHFA_enUS698US698&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=hillary%20frey">Hillary</a> and <a class="link" href="https://www.google.com/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&rlz=1C5CHFA_enUS698US698&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=mark+lotto">Mark</a> are our co-founders and are overseeing this radical experiment that they’ve bet everything on; <a class="link" href="https://www.google.com/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&rlz=1C5CHFA_enUS698US698&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=katherine+lehr">Katherine</a> is working to keep our business flexible and nimble; <a class="link" href="https://www.google.com/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&rlz=1C5CHFA_enUS698US698&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=tracy+ma">Tracy</a> ensures that our work looks and feels beautiful, deeply unique, and provocative; <a class="link" href="https://www.google.com/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&rlz=1C5CHFA_enUS698US698&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=ashley+ford">Ashley</a> and <a class="link" href="https://www.google.com/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&rlz=1C5CHFA_enUS698US698&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=rachel+syme">Rachel</a> are developing high-quality, bold stories that are timely, daring, and form-breaking; <a class="link" href="https://www.google.com/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&rlz=1C5CHFA_enUS698US698&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=ankur+thakkar">Ankur</a> is running digital experiments across platforms to build incensed fandoms around our work. In addition, we have an advisory board and a team of professionals–including an agent, attorney, accountant, and project-specific consultants—to help make stuff happen.</content><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/1rzbzTQuAzRhv_QpU7fkQ1IeMj35Z1AVdKTkGxq4aOmw/od6/public/values/dnp34'/><gsx:question>Who’s on your staff?</gsx:question><gsx:answer><img class="image image--team" src="./assets/img/team.jpg"><br>We’ve hand-picked a team of empaths who love making things and each other and making things with each other. We practice extreme transparency, collaborate on all decisions, and, to be honest, are simply v into each other. <a class="link" href="https://www.google.com/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&rlz=1C5CHFA_enUS698US698&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=hillary%20frey">Hillary</a> and <a class="link" href="https://www.google.com/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&rlz=1C5CHFA_enUS698US698&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=mark+lotto">Mark</a> are our co-founders and are overseeing this radical experiment that they’ve bet everything on; <a class="link" href="https://www.google.com/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&rlz=1C5CHFA_enUS698US698&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=katherine+lehr">Katherine</a> is working to keep our business flexible and nimble; <a class="link" href="https://www.google.com/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&rlz=1C5CHFA_enUS698US698&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=tracy+ma">Tracy</a> ensures that our work looks and feels beautiful, deeply unique, and provocative; <a class="link" href="https://www.google.com/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&rlz=1C5CHFA_enUS698US698&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=ashley+ford">Ashley</a> and <a class="link" href="https://www.google.com/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&rlz=1C5CHFA_enUS698US698&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=rachel+syme">Rachel</a> are developing high-quality, bold stories that are timely, daring, and form-breaking; <a class="link" href="https://www.google.com/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&rlz=1C5CHFA_enUS698US698&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=ankur+thakkar">Ankur</a> is running digital experiments across platforms to build incensed fandoms around our work. In addition, we have an advisory board and a team of professionals–including an agent, attorney, accountant, and project-specific consultants—to help make stuff happen.</gsx:answer></entry>
rows.title: Who’s on your staff?
rows.question: Who’s on your staff?
rows.answer: We’ve hand-picked a team of empaths who love making things and each other and making things with each other. We practice extreme transparency, collaborate on all decisions, and, to be honest, are simply v into each other. Hillary and Mark are our co-founders and are overseeing this radical experiment that they’ve bet everything on; Katherine is working to keep our business flexible and nimble; Tracy ensures that our work looks and feels beautiful, deeply unique, and provocative; Ashley and Rachel are developing high-quality, bold stories that are timely, daring, and form-breaking; Ankur is running digital experiments across platforms to build incensed fandoms around our work. In addition, we have an advisory board and a team of professionals–including an agent, attorney, accountant, and project-specific consultants—to help make stuff happen.

rows.title: An advisory board? Who’s on that?
rows.question: An advisory board? Who’s on that?
rows.answer:
• Stephen Friedman: Former president of MTV with four Emmy awards and two Peabody awards for groundbreaking pro-social campaigns, who has returned to his roots to focus on social impact and mission-driven companies
  • Akilah Hughes: A UCB-trained stand-up comedian, popular YouTube creator and 2016 resident, contributor to Fusion and MTV, fellow at the Sundance Episodic Story Lab
  • Bobbie Johnson: The Medium editor who co-founded the original Kickstarter-backed Matter and masterminded our Ellie-nominated Ghost Boat investigation
  • Laura Olin: President Obama’s 2012 social media director, creator of The Awl’s Everything Changes newsletter, and author of Form Letters
  • Lydia Polgreen: Veteran editor and foreign correspondent at The New York Times who currently leads the paper’s global expansion effort
  • Fisher Stevens: documentary filmmaker, producer, and actor, who directed Mission Blue and Before the Flood, and won the 2010 Oscar for Best Documentary Feature for co-producing The Cove

rows.question: And the board?
rows.answer: The board serves as our consultants whenever we need them. We will also grow or shrink project-specific teams depending on what we need to get the work done. All projects begin with our team, and we love making things. The creation of our visual identity, for example, was done completely in-house.

The logo’s repeating horizontal lines create a vibrating pattern that hooks the human eye, making it hard to look away from. The lines’ thicks and thins create an illusion of something that is glowing, as if lit from within. It’s designed to be applied in an aggressive way on top of something else; a headline, a paragraph, photographs, other logos. It becomes an action, a gesture. rows.title: Okay, I’m glad you mentioned that, because what is up with your logo?
rows.question: Okay, I’m glad you mentioned that, because what is up with your logo?
rows.answer: Isn’t it sick? The logo’s repeating horizontal lines create a vibrating pattern that hooks the human eye, making it hard to look away from. The lines’ thicks and thins create an illusion of something that is glowing, as if lit from within. It’s designed to be applied in an aggressive way on top of something else; a headline, a paragraph, photographs, other logos. It becomes an action, a gesture. We’re tagging something and telling people where to look.

rows.title: Right so what doesn’t do that?
rows.question: Right so what doesn’t do that?
rows.answer: Hot takes, stories that reinforce tired power structures, deeply researched investigations that explain but do not move, stories told from a removed standpoint, explorations that simply end up being boring. There are many places to publish your work, and we created Matter Studios to house the kind of storytelling that is too amorphous for traditional publishing and too powerful to ignore.

So we built a company built on that premise. It feels experimental, sure, but also...obvious?</content><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/1rzbzTQuAzRhv_QpU7fkQ1IeMj35Z1AVdKTkGxq4aOmw/od6/public/values/ea67k'/><gsx:question>It seems like so many companies are shifting their gaze to creators these days. So we built a company built on that premise. It feels experimental, sure, but also...obvious?</gsx:answer></entry>
rows.title: It seems like so many companies are shifting their gaze to creators these days. What's Matter's philosophy on creators?
rows.question: It seems like so many companies are shifting their gaze to creators these days. What's Matter's philosophy on creators?
rows.answer: If we’ve learned anything from our past experiences in tech, publishing, news, and entertainment, it’s that talented creators will find eyes and ears and minds and hearts to rally around them, particularly if people are involved in the process and inspired by the creator’s voice. So we built a company built on that premise. It feels experimental, sure, but also...obvious?

rows._xml: <entry><id>https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/1rzbzTQuAzRhv_QpU7fkQ1IeMj35Z1AVdKTkGxq4aOmw/od6/public/values/ebks1</id><updated>2016-10-26T01:21:50.928Z</updated><category scheme='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006' term='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006#list'/><title type='text'>What do you mean by having people involved in the process?</title><content type='text'>answer: Our projects will be funded and published in a strategic, iterative way. This allows us to test the work as it is made, build an audience as we go, and give our company the funding flexibility it needs. So, consider the documentarian who needs $500K and two years to create 90 minutes of film. We may start with $15,000, one month, and 10 minutes of film, and grow the project from there.</content><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/1rzbzTQuAzRhv_QpU7fkQ1IeMj35Z1AVdKTkGxq4aOmw/od6/public/values/ebks1'/><gsx:question>What do you mean by having people involved in the process?</gsx:question><gsx:answer>Our projects will be funded and published in a strategic, iterative way. This allows us to test the work as it is made, build an audience as we go, and give our company the funding flexibility it needs. So, consider the documentarian who needs $500K and two years to create 90 minutes of film. We may start with $15,000, one month, and 10 minutes of film, and grow the project from there.</gsx:answer></entry>
rows.title: What do you mean by having people involved in the process?
rows.question: What do you mean by having people involved in the process?
rows.answer: Our projects will be funded and published in a strategic, iterative way. This allows us to test the work as it is made, build an audience as we go, and give our company the funding flexibility it needs. So, consider the documentarian who needs $500K and two years to create 90 minutes of film. We may start with $15,000, one month, and 10 minutes of film, and grow the project from there.

rows.question: And you would just post those 10 minutes of film online?
rows.answer: That would be one way of giving your audience the opportunity to experience your work in process, but we could tell that story a lot of different ways. It depends on what makes the most sense for you, your project, and your audience. We want to create a world around your work.

rows.answer: That’s cool. We didn’t either. Our development executives are also talented creators who’ll be the first to tell you they didn’t want external influences to shape their work until it was beautiful and polished and perfect.

rows._xml: <entry><id>https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/1rzbzTQuAzRhv_QpU7fkQ1IeMj35Z1AVdKTkGxq4aOmw/od6/public/values/e4jxw</id><updated>2016-10-26T01:21:50.928Z</updated><category scheme='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006' term='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006#list'/><title type='text'>That’s exactly how I feel.</title><content type='text'>answer: But then the Internet happened. To all of us. And with it, the means by which we create and consume art. You’re probably already sharing your work before it’s finished without realizing it. All the articles you engage with, the conversations you find yourself in, the ideas that you amplify—what you consume and engage with is what you’re thinking about. And what you’re thinking about inevitably shapes what you’re making. Why not let the world into that process?</content><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/1rzbzTQuAzRhv_QpU7fkQ1IeMj35Z1AVdKTkGxq4aOmw/od6/public/values/e4jxw'/><gsx:question>That’s exactly how I feel.</gsx:question><gsx:answer>But then the Internet happened. All the articles you engage with, the conversations you find yourself in, the ideas that you amplify—what you consume and engage with is what you’re thinking about. And what you’re thinking about inevitably shapes what you’re making. Why not let the world into that process?</gsx:answer></entry>
rows.title: That’s exactly how I feel.
rows.question: That’s exactly how I feel.
rows.answer: But then the Internet happened. To all of us. And with it, the means by which we create and consume art. You gave this character their most tragic flaw which is that they only care about the surface of things. They read covers, never books, and this obviously has implications for how they interact with the world. Normally you’d need to clean your desk before writing and make coffee and put on <em>Kid A</em> but you wrote those 300 words in bed on your phone even though that fucking bird that loves your window was chirping out the bird translation of <em>Ulysses</em>. Your character left a job interview and drove across town for an online date that they felt a little too excited about and, as they walked into the coffee shop, your alarm went off and you remembered that you had to shower and be a person in the world. rows.title: So the 300 words I wrote this morning are art lol?
rows.question: So the 300 words I wrote this morning are art lol?
rows.answer: Okay, suppose you woke up earlier than usual this morning and checked your Twitter feed and saw a headline that made you laugh so hard you didn’t even need to read the article, and it gave you an idea for one of your characters. You gave this character their most tragic flaw which is that they only care about the surface of things. They read covers, never books, and this obviously has implications for how they interact with the world. Normally you’d need to clean your desk before writing and make coffee and put on Kid A but you wrote those 300 words in bed on your phone even though that fucking bird that loves your window was chirping out the bird translation of Ulysses. Your character left a job interview and drove across town for an online date that they felt a little too excited about and, as they walked into the coffee shop, your alarm went off and you remembered that you had to shower and be a person in the world. You got out of bed and as you walked to your window, the bird stopped chirping and turned its head toward you.

<li>Pick up smoking.</li>

rows.title: I worry that I don’t take enough risks.
rows.question: I worry that I don’t take enough risks.
rows.answer:
You should make a list of all the risky activities you haven’t been able to do yet. Here’s an example list to get you started:
  1. Pick up smoking.
  2. Make every photo in your Tinder bio a group pic with your better-looking friends who are already in relationships.
  3. Quit job to sail around the world just to write a viral Medium post to teach people how you did it.
  4. Make an egg Twitter account and infiltrate a subcommunity of incredibly angry people to dismantle them from the inside.
  5. Kick it with someone you’ve never gotten along with and tell them your fears.

rows._xml: <entry><id>https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/1rzbzTQuAzRhv_QpU7fkQ1IeMj35Z1AVdKTkGxq4aOmw/od6/public/values/a59y2</id><updated>2016-10-26T01:21:50.928Z</updated><category scheme='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006' term='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006#list'/><title type='text'>What will collaborating with you feel like?</title><content type='text'>answer: There’s this episode of <em>Black Mirror</em> in which a character played by Jon Hamm is a dating guru that helps you achieve your goals. Hamm can see and hear everything that you see and hear via this pair of contact lenses--inevitably they will be the next iteration of Google Glass--and tells you what to wear, how to stand, who to speak with, and what to say. You have at your disposal a series of Hamm-approved anecdotes designed to make people laugh while opening them up, to make them feel comfortable and interested in you as a nuanced and attractive human being. Hamm is helping you tap into humanity’s basest needs and most universal vulnerabilities and successfully coaching you to subvert them using social cues, language, and gestures, with the goal of getting a person to desire you. He does this while being a literal voice in your ear and watching your life through wearable technology. rows._xml: <entry><id>https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/1rzbzTQuAzRhv_QpU7fkQ1IeMj35Z1AVdKTkGxq4aOmw/od6/public/values/acas7</id><updated>2016-10-26T01:21:50.928Z</updated><category scheme='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006' term='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006#list'/><title type='text'>Are you happy?</title><content type='text'>answer: There are times when we are happy but not always, which is normal right? Sometimes you need to feel incensed. Sometimes you need to ugly cry. It’s funny, we’ve run a Twitter series called Elegant Services in which we made people feel with a different media type each week. We’ve done it with Vines, Bollywood gifs, power ballads, Laura Dern faces, etc. So we ask users how they want to feel. And the specificity of the feel is crucial. Instead of telling us you want to feel happy, we would need you to tell us that you want to feel like your crush invited you to his dorm room but you inadvertently knocked on the wrong door and have now just locked eyes with your true soulmate (for example). Because what is the Vine that captures that feeling? Probably <a class="link" href="https://vine.co/v/i1DKdQBQx9d">this one</a>. But what we’re trying to say here is that, yes, we can feel happy. But inside of happy, sad, anger, belonging, fear, disgust and the entire range of human emotion there are infinite ways to feel. Moreover, feeling them in powerful sequences is what the best stories do for us. Let’s make stuff like that.</content><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/1rzbzTQuAzRhv_QpU7fkQ1IeMj35Z1AVdKTkGxq4aOmw/od6/public/values/acas7'/><gsx:question>Are you happy?</gsx:question><gsx:answer>There are times when we are happy but not always, which is normal right? Instead of telling us you want to feel happy, we would need you to tell us that you want to feel like your crush invited you to his dorm room but you inadvertently knocked on the wrong door and have now just locked eyes with your true soulmate (for example). Because what is the Vine that captures that feeling? Probably <a class="link" href="https://vine.co/v/i1DKdQBQx9d">this one</a>. But what we’re trying to say here is that, yes, we can feel happy. But inside of happy, sad, anger, belonging, fear, disgust and the entire range of human emotion there are infinite ways to feel. Moreover, feeling them in powerful sequences is what the best stories do for us. Let’s make stuff like that.</gsx:answer></entry>

rows.question: Are you happy?
rows.answer: There are times when we are happy but not always, which is normal right? Sometimes you need to feel incensed. Sometimes you need to ugly cry. It’s funny, we’ve run a Twitter series called Elegant Services in which we made people feel with a different media type each week. We’ve done it with Vines, Bollywood gifs, power ballads, Laura Dern faces, etc. So we ask users how they want to feel. And the specificity of the feel is crucial. Instead of telling us you want to feel happy, we would need you to tell us that you want to feel like your crush invited you to his dorm room but you inadvertently knocked on the wrong door and have now just locked eyes with your true soulmate (for example). Because what is the Vine that captures that feeling? Probably this one. But what we’re trying to say here is that, yes, we can feel happy. But inside of happy, sad, anger, belonging, fear, disgust and the entire range of human emotion there are infinite ways to feel. Moreover, feeling them in powerful sequences is what the best stories do for us. Let’s make stuff like that.
